Archery and fencing are the two disciplines this book uses to expose Zen buddhism's practices and nature.

It does so with the simple narrative of the author's journey in mastering archery through "art without artifice".

This means learning the act of shooting an arrow to become as natural, unconscious and effortless as an apple falling from from a tree.

It works very well as the tool to expose the methods and philosophy behind it, which then parallels to any skill or discipline we can set for ourselves.

The main skill to learn being, rather than the actual physical skill of shooting arrows, learning to detach ourselves from the objective and allowing "it" (the unconscious) to take the reins.
